content.description: SDS on the left side of the south face. Staying out of the arete and the crack climb straight up using pockets/pinches. Careful as holds will pull off from time to time.
SDS in the crack on the south face and move up and right.  At the right arete climb straight up on pinches and small pockets.  The crux is figuring out which pockets to use.
Stand start on the obvious double side pull and feet on smeer. Slap up to the horizontal jug and pockets to the top. Fun route!
content.location: directly to the left of the northeast face route (V4)...

content.description: SDS on the obvious holds and terrible feet on the left side of the northeast arete.  Move up on left on small crimps and pinches.  Top out to the left
content.location: The east side on the northeast arete

content.description: SDS on face holds next to the Y crack.  Climb straight up between the Y-crack.  All parts of the crack is off which force you into some very interesting moves.
SDS start in the Y crack.  Take the left hand version.  Good warm up
SDS in the crack which makes a Y.  Take the right hand version.  Probably 5.8 or 5.9 climbing

This route starts on the west side of the large crack, work your way staying as low as possible without touching the ground, don't use the top for an extra challenge. The lower you go the harder it is. This route may be harder for taller people.
content.protection: Don't fall in the crack, it will scrape you up.
content.location: This is easy to find, start on the north facing small wall and work into the giant crack in the middle of the boulder.

content.description: Sit start with your left hand on a crimp, right hand undercling pinch, and anything you can find for feet.  Shoot your left hand to a poor half pad two finger pocket.  Then dyno for one of two thank god pockets at the lip. Catch this and it's over just top out.  The crux is keep your feet on the rock after the first move.
content.location: upper part of the west face

content.description: Start right hand on a decent side pull and left on small two finger crimp.  Work your feet up and make a dynamic move to a small crimp.  Work your feet up again and go for the jug at the lip.  Finish with the easy top out.  Crux is catching the crimp and moving off of it.
content.location: On the face to the right of the Y crack on the north end of the boulder.

content.description: SDS in the hand crack on the south face.  Follow it till it ends on the north side of the boulder and top out.  Fun warm up high off the ground
content.location: The obvious large crack that divides the boulder.  If you can't find this you need an IQ test

content.description: Originally found by Avery so it has been dubbed the Avery boulder.  The holds on this thing are sooo unique.  Most of the holds consist of two finger pockets or pinches with good friction.  The only down side is it tears up the fingers.  Landings are flat and top outs are pretty solid.  This is faily new so there are several FA's waiting to be had.
